# Authentication

:::note MAC

Message Authentication Code

Still SKES.
So it makes sure that the message is from the correct person.

![](image-kkk9u4pv.png)
:::

![](image-kkk9v2c6.png)

![](image-kkk9xk1y.png)

So importantly, there's no confidentiality or non-repudiation. So **observers can see the message $x$**. Also, There's **no way for Bob to prove to someone else that the message came from Alice**; that would require letting them in on the key. Bob could have generated the MAC himself anyway. **Bob could fake a message to himself**, as if it came from Alice.

Replay is also something you have to watch out for.

![](image-kkka43mh.png)

So, to be clear, the attacker can have any message tagged by Alice or Bob, but the attacker has to come up with a tag for any message by themselves, without this "tagging oracle". So the attacker can know almost any message-tag pair they want, but they have to derive a new one on their own for the attack to succeed.

![](image-kkka7j7w.png)

![](image-kkka86ih.png)

## V2b

![](image-kkk9f3m8.png)

But how would we use these for encryption using a key?

![](image-kkk9ho6x.png)

![](image-kkk9idbh.png)

This one is really just a slight problem. Where if you find a collision, and you find the tag of one (through the tagging oracle), then you can know the tag of the other.

Collisions were found for MD4 and MD5, so the community was very weary of collisions as a potential weakness. As a result, they didn't like this small problem.

![](image-kkkb7f3u.png)

![](image-kkkb843l.png)
The constants are arbitrary, but they're fixed and also different.

![](image-kkkbb2b3.png)

You can break into a phone and get a key $k$. Or you could break into the service provider and yoink their database. Or you could go to Gemalto...
